column81: The warrant officer was very unhelpful and obstructive throughout the processes of gaining warrant approval. This made the whole process very protracted.
column83: The warrant reports were terrible and not constructive. The warrant officer would not discuss the application so it was impossible to get any direction on requirements and despite numerous resubmissions most of the comments remained. I have never in over 20yrs experienced such wilful obstruction.
column87: The entire service was totally dysfunctional in this instance. The only reason I note the response time as poor and not very poor is because the officer returned warrant reports very quickly. The reports however took no cognisance of the revised submission and just repeated the same points.
column89: Fairness was even a consideration. My experience was of a wilful and malicious abuse of authority.
column91: As noted in all answers above they service received was not only totally unacceptable I seemed to be subject to the will of a surveyor who had gone totally rouge. I did have commutations with his line manager and at one stage was told that there were know issues and its implied that there was nothing that could be done avoid the issues. This is totally unacceptable. I believe that the there were potentially health issues with the surveyor , but I think that it is a total management failure that they were left to operate unsupervised. This caused a great deal of stress for me personally and also the client, not to mention the consequential delay and expense.
column92: I would like the council to ensure that management structures are put in place to monitor and help all of their staff to ensure that this kind of lapse is not possible. I think it's damaging for all involved.

column24: As I am not employed within the building trade, I gained confidence dealing with, what I felt was a complicated process, that I was very unfamiliar with. Dealing with the NL Building Standards contact, took me through the process, which I was very thankful for.

column30: As this warrant was issued during the Covid-19 pandemic, with people working from home, I expected delays due to the constraints the pandemic brought. However, when I required to get in touch with NL Building Standards, I was put onto a messaging service. On leaving my message, my contact always get in touch within 24 hours, I which I thought was reasonable, under the circumstances
column32: There were a couple of minor issues that the Building Standards picked up, that had to be rectified, that were explained to me in detail, that were in fact rectified by builder, and evidence submitted to contact which was accepted. This part of the process gave me satisfaction that the job was being completed to the warrant content, and felt this was a fair process.
column34: As per last question.
column53: I thought that with the type of work that was being carried out, ie wall coming down and the fitting of support beams, the warrant called for me to contact Building Standards at the point of props being fitted, then when beams were in place, I thought this meant there would be visits at these points to check they were being fitted as per warrant specification. However, on contact I was advised to send in photographs at these stages. I sent in detailed photos of both stages, which is were  a couple of minor issues were picked up and rectified. I am aware that due to Covid-19 this had it’s limitations.
column55: The building warrant approval process was very straight forward, made easier by the BS contact.

The e-building website is far and away the worst website I have ever used, and I speak as someone recently retired from 20+ years as a usability expert. My description of it as the worst I have ever come across is not exaggeration or hyperbole, it is the literal truth. 

Your helpdesk are clearly aware of its uselessness as they have a preprepared document claiming to help users with the type of problem I had (simply trying to upload a single pdf file of my electrical completion certificate)

Daqniel O'Hara in the planning department is also aware of how unusable the site is as he too has a pre-prepared helpsheet. I've wasted quite enough time on your stinking pile of shit and I am not prepared to waste further time on it or on this feedback. If you'd like me to fix it for you, call me and we can discuss it further.

Our client is a small business owner who unlike many operators took the time and consideration to 
apply for all permissions and has been treated very poorly.
column89:
My own mother was in a wheelchair for 11 years and as such never liked being singled out or to feel awkward in any given situation . The view of most wheelchair users is to be treated no differently than that of any member of the public. Bearing this in mind the officer insisted on the formation of an area no bigger than the turning circle of a wheelchair within a unit whereby other customers could simply look down on this area as if they were a paria. 
The Building Regulations are recommendations and not designed to make building users feel awkward and are to be singled out. A view on this should have been taken as adjoing units have no access for wheelchair users which is clearly not possible.
column91:
The Building Control officer's report asked that we provide Gas details and certification , the Building has no gas.
He asked for details on a servery shutter , there is no such shutter.
He asked for details on locks to doors which have no locks .
He requested head heights which were indicated on the drawings
He wanted details on a 4" fan and an electric water heater
and on and on and on all clearly stalling tactics.
column92: We are now advising clients that should a warrant be required in Edinburgh they should look to use another practice or go to another City anywhere in the UK . Life is too short to deal with such a petty council who's department clearly couldn't care less about incoming business.

column81: A wall of silence. I send an email, no reply. I leave a phone message, no reply. I get told to send an attachment only to get an automated reply saying "we can't accept emails with attachments". Just completely unhelpful from start to finish. I could list dozens of similar examples. You know the ONE time during the whole process I got a fast response? When the council was asking me for more money - that response I got in a day and a half. Everything else I wait months for. Then, I get an email saying my case has been transfered to someone else at the council - it's like a magical switch has been flicked - I get responses to email in a day or two - this person is helpful, tells me what paragraphs of building code to read in order to comply etc. Its amazing that the whole customer experience completely depends on whos desk your application happens to land on. So to sum up, Marianne Benzie is a wonderful employee who should be given a raise, and Nasma Sattar should either undergo extensive retraining or be fired.

column83: Often several Building Standards Surveyors will be involved in the same application. One at the time before granting the Warrant, another for the site inspection, another for any Amendment of Warrant and maybe another for an further inspection. Consistency between BSSs is an issue

column83: The Building Control officer is and has been extremely difficulty to get a response from with waiting times up to 2 months before receiving any feedback to communications. column87: The Building Control officer is and has been extremely difficulty to get a response from with waiting times up to 2 months before receiving any feedback to communications. Information included within certain BCO queries have been unclear at times and with the long response times to get any information from the assigned BCO, gaining clarity on these items has been difficult and presented delays to the purification of consents.  Additionally, we have found that Building Control had repeatedly attempted to pass on missed items of non compliance from the building shell application onto out fitout application in order to get these items resolved.  This is an unacceptable tactic to try and pass on any errors previously made by Edinburgh council onto an applicant in order to get these resolved.
column89: We have found that Building Control had repeatedly attempted to pass on missed items of non compliance from the building shell application onto out fitout application in order to get these items resolved. The Scottish attempt tries to cover every eventuality but fails miserably. column20: Copy of a completion certificate which was never received
column24:
I first had to call access line who passed on my message, I was called back about 2 hours later.
I then was to.d I would need to pay £25 for a copy of a certificate I did not receive in the first place, I made the payment immediately, I was then sent an email advising I could not get the certificate until the next afternoon as the payments team would need to notify the building standards team but was assured I would have it the next afternoon. I did not receive it the next afternoon and tried to call the lady at 4pm on the afternoon in question but the call was not answered and I left a message requesting a callback - I have never received this yet. I also sent an email that evening as I still had heard nothing. I received an email stating the next morning stating that I would need to wait until that afternoon until the payments team could tell her if the payment was in. This was then followed swiftly by another email stating she had in fact got an email the day before advising payment had in fact been received and she could issue a copy certificate. The fact that she had not bothered to check emails or even acknowledge the voicemail left is very disappointing.

column87:
You say you aim to get in touch, but this is by means of a standard letter really. It is only if you require further information you now get in touch, otherwise we are waiting and waiting and then its up to the agent to chase applications where are previously we would have building control contact us as let us know they are dealing with the application.

Also there is nothing worse than providing outstanding documents at completion and then having building control issue out a further report, with the same points on the list (WITH NO FURTHER DESCRIPTION / COMMENTS TO CLARIFY WHAT THEY ARE ACTUALLY LOOKING FOR) just the same point noted again, and this happens on a continual basis and is infuriating.
column89:
I have had a couple of run ins with one officer in particular who tends to only deal with completion. I have had him shout down the phone at me to "hurry up" with my response regarding a report when I was in the middle of looking for the piece of information to provide.

I think given covid and the current situation your officers need to be more pro-active and be more patient.
column91: Not enough consistency
column92:

I must also note I have had some other officers have been great, back in touch within the same day even however unfortunately this is rarely the case,

column81: We submitted an application for Amendment to Building Warrant on 8th March 2022. On 30th May 2022 we were forced raised an escalation, as the assigned building warrant officer, Craig MacLeod, was impossible to contact to progress the application.
column83:
We submitted an application for Amendment to Building Warrant on 8th March 2022. On 30th May 2022 we were forced raised an escalation, as the assigned building warrant officer, Craig MacLeod, was impossible to contact to progress the application.

Once escalated to Daniel Henderson, the application was dealt with swiftly and approved 15th June 2022.
column87:
From raising an amendment to warrant to filing for completion we dealt with 4 building warrant officers over a period of 5.5 months. At both warrant stage and completion stage we were forced to escalate issues to team leaders, due to poor service / information provided by assigned officers:

Warrant Stage
Craig Macleod - Very poor service. Impossible to contact. Lack of clarity on building warrant faults letters. 
Daniel Henderson - Great service. Good / prompt communication and clarity of information.

Completion Stage
Jim Henderson - Prompt communication although fairly abrupt to deal with. Provided conflicting information and disagreed with resolutions already made by other building warrant officers at warrant stage resulting in additional work and information gathering.
Gary Gilruth - Great service. Good / prompt communication and clarity of information.
column91: A process that should have taken a matter of weeks, took 5.5 months and 4 warrant officers to resolve.

column20: To request copy of conservatory construction completion certificate
column24:
My enquiry related to  obtaining a copy of my conservatory completion certificate .
The construction was completed in 2005.  My initial enquiry was by e mail on morning of 31August 2022 and I had a positive response that afternoon.  The response detailed procedure to follow in order to obtain the document. I followed the procedure on the morning of 1 September 2033 around 0915 hours and received an e mail copy of the certificate at 1606 hours same day.

Actually speaking to an officer was extremely difficult. Advice on the Council website regards this department was incorrect. Only when I pushed on a point did progress happen.
column35:
My experience was one where the Council no longer exists to serve the people within the city, but to put up reasons why some simple task can't be done.
I call on council services very rarely. I have worked in local government for over a decade and to an extent understand the demands placed on it. I am a reasonable and educated individual but found the Glasgow City Council almost impenetrable. Front line staff appear to lack basic knowledge of the service they provide. Officers are only available at certain point of the day and days of the week. I had to badger and push to get a sensible conversation to explain my situation, ask questions as to what was required of me in order to expedite my reason for calling on the council service. The senior officer (Head of Service) was very helpful, but the level of information I was seeking should be provided by front line staff, not senior management!!!
Please can Glasgow City cease using their automated phone call routing and employ humans with an understanding of Council services and can direct calls to another human. The phone system is clearly designed to put people off making contact with the council or give up very quickly on their journey.

column26: Generally no issues with the standard of communication with the exception of the 'Deemed refusal' that came in a few years back.  I accept that this was brought in to prevent developers sitting on swathes of land and applications for years before progressing but in the case of domestic projects it can cause some issues.  I often have several projects on the go at one time and that includes both planning and warrant.  In that case it's really easy to loose track of timeframes for projects especially when dealing with a client who is either changing their mind or wants to approach a project at their pace on site.  Similarly obtaining tenders is now almost impossible in the old school 3 week timeframe and in some cases can be months.  I think both planning & building standards need to have clear contact instructions from an agent prior to issuing a deemed refusal.  This often doesn't happen and can lead to having to re-apply which really is a waste of time for both the agent and Building Standards.  Whikst I can see the need for the process I think there should be a better way of handling it.

column81:
In the main response times are acceptable and where the initial timetable cannot be achieved, many building control officers are communicating this.
However, there remains a culture of hiding behind the standard 10 day automatic response email, this is incredibly frustrating when trying to agree an acceptable solution to an issue by email when a simple conversation is drawn out over months, as each response is cryptic and also 10 days apart - this is appalling.
column83:
Initial automatic letters are adequate.
Initial building warrant reports are mostly adequate, but in several cases the clipped language used, makes it difficult to understand what it is that is a problem - there is not enough description provided to make a meaningful response without substantial guesswork on our part.
column87:
The points I raise above try to set out where we see the problems.
In addition, there are known members of the buuilding control team who are approaching their role in a completely different way to the rest of the team, meaning there are obvious inconsistencies in service and communication provided.
A major problem that we see is the reluctance to do site inspections during the works, to look at drainage, structure etc. while the work is ongoing. This was a valued service in days past.
Along with that, there the helpdesk has been scaled back to a meaningless service, it is ineffectual, remote, inaccessible and completely not fit for purpose.
This is exacerbated by officers who are unapproachable, uncontactable and hiding being behind 10 day automatic response emails.
There is also major flaw in the continuity of service now when different teams and therefor individuals are preparing reports on projects to the individuals dealing with completion inspections. Their expectations of what should have been included in a warrant or not varies wildly and there is no accountability between them with several inspections raising new points long after there is a point to easily address them ie when it is on a drawing - this is by far one of the most disappointing, bordering on terrible, effects of the recent changes introduced to the systems.
column89: Overall, most staff are fair, although as mentioned about, there remain a few maverick officers who are simply not fair and have such a personalised view of what is required, it is almost impossible to find acceptable solutions.
column91:
Please take note of the previous points.
It feels as though the level of service and accountability has been substantially diminished since covid measures were introduced 3 years ago now and it does not appear the council have any awareness of this, or at least if they are, they are content with it as it suits their needs rather than serving the public.

The answer is always 'the designer is responsible' but we are not building standards experts, it is part of our job yes, but we do not specialize in it, that is your job, my client's are paying you for that service and in some instances your fees are higher than mine so my client deserve a professional service.

column35:
Some uncertainty remains around whether Surveyors are carrying out site visits or are accepting photographic evidence. It can vary from Surveyor to Surveyor (and also Local Authority to Local Authority) making it difficult for us to advise Applicants, particularly when we are not taking the project through the construction stage. 

Requests to view previous Building Warrant applicants (BSP18 forms) are still being declined. It was very helpful previously when we were able to attend EAC offices to view files. It meant that level of information contained in Building Warrant applications (where it was an existing property) that we submitted was of greater detail and accuracy and as there had been prior dialogue with the Building Standards team before submitting the application it meant that the application process went more smoothly.

column24: East Ayrshire are approachable and knowledgeable and work well with the Agent/Client to process, consider and advise on applications. The responses from the surveyors are meaningful and considered.
column26: East Ayrshire provide much clearer communication than a lot of other local authorities, both in terms of the documentation and also the timescales / points of contact. The surveyors are easy to communicate with either via telephone or email, and the result is that many issues are resolved promptly - which is a benefit to all parties.
column30:
Quality of the information provided - Sending a link to the approved drawings, as well as Building Warrant, is useful and keeps the communication clear. This is preferable to other local authorities who provide online services, or have lengthy delays in providing documentation. The information is clear to understand. 

Service offered by staff - The members of staff (surveyors via phoneline and email) are willing to take time to explain queries and this leads to much better communication. Being able to speak directly to the assigned surveyor helps greatly in streamlining the process and is appreciated.
column32: Building Standards at EAC have always been willing to engage and communicate directly and promptly.
column34: EAC Building Standards is one of the most efficient services, and highlights the shortcomings of other local authorities.

column81:
I've had a pretty disappointing experience with CEC Building standards including trying to obtain a completion certificate that took about 18 months to resolve due to almost no communication from the case officer.
Building warrant applications appear to be assessed in a hap hazard way with a view to finding problems and obstacles rather than being customer focused to find a resolution.  I have also experienced a long wait for a dispute resolution process which appears non transparent and involves a closed group of Building Standards authorities not the wider profession, therefore I think it is biased.  Across all authorities I think there is far too much inconsistency of evaluating building warrant applications and too much autonomy by individual case officers with no oversight leaving agents and applicants at their mercy.  There appears to be no understanding of the wider profession and overall stages in a construction project.  A building warrant is half way through an architects service for example.  A building warrant is there to show technical compliance and we shouldn't be expected to provide extensive construction details to satisfy individual officers.  This process costs time and money and each request either causes a cost to the agent or directly to the applicant.  We are so frustrated with the process now that we charge additional fees to clients post warrant submission to allow for the sometime extensive work required to obtain a building warrant.
column83: I have received a report from building standards that are clearly "save as" or "cut and paste" from another report with no relation to the specific project.  I also find the reports vague in what they are asking for - be more direct in identifying the specific Building standards clause or requirement - don't leave the agent guessing.

The build was during covid and building materials were scarce and difficult to source. There was an occasion where they came back and said that a certain thing hadn't been done/used. I was upset because
1. How they knew this was never explained and led me to believe that a neighbour with a grudge ( and possibly a contact in the department) had reported this. This could have caused upset with said neighbour had I chosen to pursue it. No member of the department had presented themselves to me or my builder at the time of submission. 
2. My builder had been unable to source the original proposed materials, (covid shortages) so had to adapt. 
3. It cost me a further, not insubstantial  fee to my Architectural Technician and a resubmission. The change was perfectly acceptable to the dept  on resubmission.

column37: Direct emails and phone calls between agent and BS officer have been dealt with promptly. There has however been an issue with paperwork not being issued to the correct email address by WLC.
column39: Paperwork (crit sheets, amendments, etc) not sent out to correct email address by WLC. This has been pointed out to Building Standards officer on numerous occasions yet is still happening.
column46: There have been a number of items outwith the Technical Standards which we have had issues with BS. This includes Magnalocks & Labss reports.
column48:
BS requesting additional works on site at completion stage which are outwith the Domestic Technical Standards and outwith previously approved BW drawings (Magnalocks). The reason for this was a WLC Building Standards Technical note which was not made available prior to completion application.

BS requesting additional works due to LABSS report which the LABSS paper author confirmed was not required, this item cost an additional 5-figure sum to the project (LABSS paper INFOP24).

The project involved a Staged application (Stage 1 - substructure - foundations, drainage, etc & Stage 2 - superstructure). When the 1st Amendment to Warrant application was made it was rejected because the amendments related to both Stage 1 and Stage 2, WLC requested 2no. separate Amendment applications were made for this. This is not noted in the Procedural Handbook, WLC were effectively asking for an 'Amendment to an Amendment' application, no proper explanation was giving for this other than it is how WLC always operate.
column50:
The BS officers dealt with on site and during the warrant application stage were professional and forthcoming with information. 
The issues we have experienced have cost a great deal of labour and monies across this project and appear to stem from a managerial level within WLC. There is a culture of appearing to be 'consistent' within WLC however it is our opinion that this is 'inconsistent' with all other local authorities across Scotland. The issues we have faced are outwith the Technical Standards and Procedural Handbooks and it is clear that WLC are making their own rules regarding Building Standards compliance.

column34: I asked many roofing contractors in my area if the work needed a Building Warrant and every one stated they did not. When I explained this to the section manager, that this work was being carried in my own road,  I was told they cannot check every roofing contractor.
column35: The council stated that I need a Building Warrant where all other roofing contractors stated I don’t.  This has left me in a state of limbo with an ageing roof that I cannot change as no contractor knows how to apply for a Building Warrant with appropriate drawings. column24:
Application made in Feb 2022, several emails and calls back and forth and by January 2023 still no decision. My application is for the build of a cattery business and through un-neccessary delays by the Planning Department for the Consent I have already lost the best part of two years trading. Building Standards admit they ahve no previous experience of usch a buidling but refuse to take any recognition of other businesses which have been creatd in other parts of Scotland using the smae manufacturer of materials. I ahve even gone to the added expense of commissioning a Structural Engineer to create calculations for the structure because the officer seems unwilling to accept that this building will not be occupied or frequented by members of the public. It will be occupied by CATS!! 
Renfrewshire Planning AND now Building Standards are certainly carving out a terrible reputation for stalling the creation of new SME's in the region and providing the support they ought to be to constituents playing council taxes.
column26:
Calls, emails just simply not answered and then promises of any progress not being held to and another week passes by etc etc.......
Ultimately the applicant (me) is left to feel awkward about "hounding" the officer for a decision - despite being several thousand pounds out of pocket and left with the feeling that "if he (officer/surveyor)  simply cannot understand what is being proposed (because of a lack of experience and an unwilling ness to learn from those who DO know) without even being willing to conduct a site visit, then he can merely refuse the warrant and then have me put to more inconvenience and further delay by having to follow an appeal process"

column37: I normally work in Edinburgh and this was my first project in West Lothian and it was covered by the West team - I found the surveyors whilst strict, they were very helpful, professional and courteous at all stages. It was refreshing to get a positive input from Building Control during a project. They offered a good response time, explained CCP visits to both myself and the client which made the process actually easier and gave the client peace of mind. My client was telling one of the surveyors that he had previously built an extension approx 6 years ago and had received an excellent service then and he said that a Mr Johnston had looked after it - the surveyor said that Mr Johnston was now his boss, so he is obviously passing on his knowledge and attitude to his team!

I believe defects have been missed with no opportunity to show or explain to the inspector. I do not believe the certificate should have been issued.
column35:
As mentioned in the survey it was not myself who issued the request for the building completion certificate at 7 Oliphant way Kirkcaldy. It was the previous owner and I understand that all correspondence will have went through them. However I have purchased the property before the certificate was issued and before inspection has taken place. There are 2 issues that I believe have not been picked up at the inspector who visits the property and there has been no opportunity for me to talk to someone about it. 
The first issue being the window to the front of the extension had not being sealed underneath the sill leaving a 30mm gap and allowing a draft into the room. 
Second issue being the decorative cast stone under the window is completely loose and you can move by hand. I have young children and this is very dangerous. I’m not sure if this helps support the window. I am very concerned and confused to why this has not been picked up on the day of the survey. 
Please reply to 

scottygou@hotmail.com

Or 

Scott Gourlay
7 Oliphant way
Kirkcaldy
KY26TF

column81: I originally phoned the Council and was given a number to contact in order to leave a message. I was told that an appropriate person would get back to me. This is exactly what happened. Very efficient.
column83: The standard of communication provided by Tony McArthur is excellent. He takes time to listen carefully and he answers all queries in a clear and informative manner whether this is by phone or email. At the end of a phone call, he always says ‘Just get back to me if you have have any more questions’. That means a lot. It is enormously reassuring to know that there are professionals at the Council who are available to be contacted in this way in order to offer advice, guidance and support.
column87:
I have had a first class service from Tony McArthur in every way. Friendly, professional, respectful, informative, timely, efficient and caring. 
One of my questions was to ask how to go about obtaining building warrant plans for our new home. Tony gave me the number for Tony Gilhooly at Planning and advised on the cost of plans, etc. Tony Gilhooly was also very friendly and efficient.
column91: I have had a very positive experience in dealing with Tony McArthur at Building Standards. It is enormously reassuring to know that the Council is there for its citizens and willing to help, advise and support. To be able to actually ‘reach’ a professional these days and to be able to discuss things with them on the phone (as opposed to chatting online or email) is a rare thing and something that I have appreciated very much.
column92: Thank you to Edinburgh City Council. My husband and I are super impressed by the way Building Standards have communicated with me and my queries and we are very grateful. Please keep enabling your surveyors to be able to discuss things with citizens directly on the phone. It means the world to know you can be in touch with professionals who are knowledgeable and willing to help.

column24: This is the second time that I have used Falkirk building standards. On both occasions I found the team to be very knowledgeable, helpful and always there to answer any questions that I may have had, even though they, themselves were always busy and under pressure. Through time, dealing with certain individuals, you built up a rapport. I have been in the building trade a long time, but have to say, through all the various councils and building control officers and staff, I have to say that many excelled in giving information or help that was timely, when promised, often getting back to me, before an agreed timeline which I have not experienced anywhere else, nor heard of this from others, whom I have worked with in the past and shared experiences. The staff should be proud of themselves for delivering a top class service and setting standards that can only be admired.
column26: All communication, was timely, often before agreed timelines, which was very helpful and often these guys went above and beyond.
column30: I never had any issues with any staff as I found everybody to be committed to their job, from going into the building early in the morning to hand in paperwork, long before office staff started, it was taken from me and put behind the desk to be dealt with by staff upon arrival, handing in paperwork or drawings etc, the staff were always kind and considerate and nothing was a problem. If I needed to speak to a building control officer, they would come through to answer a query, despite being busy. I was always impressed by the attention and length the staff would go to in order to help me.
column32: The staff are professional to be approached on any level, from somebody who is used to dealing with building standards on a daily basis, or somebody who just does a bit of DIY and is not used to the terminology of a construction environment. Either way, I found I was always treated with respect and during lockdown, where times were tough, certain staff shone through Covid.
column34: Certain Individuals over the years made my experience enjoyable, despite having a few complications along the way on my build, I was able to talk to them and find solutions. Sadly some of these guys have retired now and will be missed by their colleagues and many of the builders whom they built up solid reputations and friendships over the years. I am grateful that my experience was made better by working with these individuals.
column35: During my build, it was fraught with problems, always the way with a renovation. I had family who were unwell and I lost, made redundant twice due to circumstances out with my control and a whole host of general problems that most people and family have daily. My building control officer, Mr D Hale whom I have the utmost respect for, for helping me get through some tough moments, by granting me extensions when my timing was wrong or we had bad news and struggled in general. He was always there when I needed a question answered, or advice for an alteration, or clarification, which was quite a lot. In all honesty, He was Fantastic with how he treated me and my family when we needed compassion and wriggle room when life was not going as per the plan. This is why I rate building control so highly, because of the level of sheer professionalism that was given to me, more so when Covid reared it's ugly head. Tough times yet these guys, continued to work from home on a different level which can only be admired.  Another situation when Covid Came, my Building warrant ran out and try as I might, I could not get through to FDC to renew as the phone lines could not cope and crashed. I eventually managed to leave a phone message, and A gentleman Called Colin Called me back. I explained my problem, which he fixed there and then. The sheer relief was unbelievable and the worry went away over night, just by Colin calling me back and talking about my dilemma, which he fixed. I emailed Colin several times over the course of Covid, and always got the same response, helpful, kind and considerate. He recognised my problem, yet took ownership of it and made it his own. I slept well that night all due to his actions which, can and never will be underestimated and I am grateful for Colin making the time, when he admitted to me, he was swamped by many other callers in similar positions. And when you look at the situation, these two individuals stand out, because, they not only are Professional in their chosen trade, but were not prepared for Covid like the rest of us, yet rose to the challenge and went by far and above the call of duty that was expected of them at that time. I am truly in their debt for all they have done for me and can only speak highly of the building standards at Falkirk Council.

column81: I was able to arrange a meeting with both the surveyor dealing with the application and the manager with whom the application was discussed internally. We were able to review a few different possibilities for an alternative method of compliance over a period of 10-15 minutes, establishing the principles of a possible approach. Much of my practice's work deals with tricky alterations to existing buildings, with live applications in 6 or 7 local authorities. Many of those BC departments take a much less collegiate approach to dealing with unusual situations, which I believe creates additional work for all involved.
column83: Not the most timely in the first instance, but considering that the query was reviewed by senior members of staff, that is understandable. The outcomes of internal discussions were explained to me clearly and concisely, establishing the basis for a productive conversation about how to reach a solution.
column89: There is a great deal of variation in how alternative methods of compliance are interpreted by different councils, and often by individual case officers. Knowing that the specifics of the situation triggered an internal discussion and an attempt to establish a clear approach for similar situations is reassuring.

column81: I'm not sure which project this query refers to so I have responded generally. It would greatly help to be able to speak with a building control officer at any point!  This used to be commonplace precovid.  Speaking with an officer helps particularly pre warrant submission and critically when works start on site as proposed construction often has to change due to unforeseen site issues but its almost impossible to get a response and certainly not soon enough to assist on site.  Also a 10 day turn around response time is not practical with domestic site works.  I don't think in the past few years I've had a reply from building control within 10 days, its taken weeks longer and usually I give up trying!  I understand that warrant officers are under resourced but if builders and architects can't speak with building contro,l building standards will inevitably suffer.

column35: We would record our appreciation to Fife Building Control and Mr Keith Bowman in particular. We applied for a Retrospective Building Warrant for the removal of two walls in the house carried out by the previous owners. Despite there being no indication of poor workmanship and a reassuring report by Colin Aitkin of Aitkin Property Consultancy in Leven (the vendor's appointed surveyor), Mr. Bowman insisted that the beam installations be properly structurally assessed. Thank goodness he did. On detailed inspection it soon became apparent that the  previous work was of poor standard and could have resulted in severe structural problems in the future. Please pass my appreciation on to Keith Bowman.

column35: The Scottish Government's document covering the "customer journey" of the building warrant process sets a very high standard of expectation; and the legal stipulations of Schedule Three appeared to me to be straightforward.  An old flat that has been empty for 25 years is liable to need a lot of repair, without a definite requirement for a building warrant.  At the same time, the option of just leaving the building to rot is not available, as there is another duplex flat sitting above!  The fact that the flat lies in a conservation zone does not affect the operation of Schedule Three, as far as I can see.

column35: During an already stressful time, the fact that it came to light that I did not have the required completion certificate caused me even more stress. I explained this to Paul Donnelly over the phone and he was very understanding, but when he came out to the property to inspect the work done, he had to inform me that he couldn't provide the completion certificate as the work did not match the plans submitted. He advised me what I needed to do and went above and beyond to ensure that everything was done to ensure that the completion certificate was provided on time for my house sale to go through. Not having any experience of building works and the rules and regulations that go with it the help and advice Paul offered during that time was invaluable and hugely appreciated making a very stressful and trying situation a little easier to bear.

column81:
I have been waiting OVER TWO YEARS for completion certificate
The first inspector was Mariane Benzie with whom there were countless delays and muddles due to her being on sick leave etc.
A new inspector Michael Jones came onboard a year ago and we corrected the faults he found.
The architect submitted all the documents to the portal.
It was discovered that our case number was listed under two different addresses.
Mr Jones contacted on 25 July this year to say he would look into why he did not find our document on the portal and get back to us in two days.
It is now 14 August and we have heard nothing from Mr Jones, despite emails and the architect's offer to telephone.

This has been a situation in which I, the owner, have exerted almost superhuman patience, but I am now at the end of my tether

The forms did not print effectively.

column30: communication was good however requirements could have been better explained so that the required solution could have been reached quicker

When on site, the Planning Officer did not advise of all observations he had made around what was stated on the drawings and what the builders had done which differed slightly.  This resulted in me incurring a lot more costs as a result of putting in different amendments, having revised drawings completed and submitted as part of these additional applications.  If I had all the information at the one time, I would have been able to either ensure the builders completed work in a particular way that did not necessitate amendments to both drawings and work carried out and therefore not incurring different amendment applications and fees.  This added much cost and stress at a time when we were trying to complete works for a very frail member of our family in order to give him a comfortable space to live in.  Furthermore, the Planning Officer questioned our electrician's credentials and asked for proof of their SELECT membership twice.  If he had read the email sent to him by the electrician the first time he would not have had to request it twice.  This further delayed receipt of a completion certificate.
column35: It is hard to offer constructive criticism of a member of the Planning and regulatory Services department of the council as an applicant, as it may prejudice the outcome of their work i.e. not granting a completion certificate or the like.  I have found the process quite difficult for the reasons outlined above.  I felt it could have been a smoother process and was made unnecessarily difficult at a difficult time in our lives, which, granted, may have coloured our perception of the process somewhat.  However, we incurred additional fees unnecessarily in my view.

column81:
Fist problem arose when Marianne Benzie City of Edinburgh Planning and Transport, rejected our detailed application for a garage conversion citing about 16 points for grounds to refuse. Some rejections of our proposal were truly foolish e.g. uneccessary insulation, a spill test even though the garage was to be "lost", she confused requirements for new properties and conversions in existing properties, sound testing on existing party walls, calculations of total area permissible overlooking a step in the wall concerned, demands for new internal door openings to be wider than the existing outside doors (which were to be untouched!), etc. I had to pay an extra £500.00 for architect time to consider and reply to these "spurious" points. And then suddenly 
Marianne Benzie withdrew every objection - after I had paid the extra architect fee. As a boss I think the event indicated a lack of checking of MB's work by more experienced staff.
column83: MB's colleague, Csaba Tabor became our point of contact.
column87: Although Csaba Tabor was a great improvement upon Marianne Benzie, he did forget, when doing his last site visit, to detail to me what final certificates were needed, e.g. electrical safety certificate. This were requested after the visit whereas it would have been better to do so on site.

column24: The continued letters of request for further information added no value to either the design or construction process. It should take a BCO only one letter to request any additional information they require, not 5 or 6!

column30: As an Architects / Agent who specialises (only) in low energy & passive housing we find that there is no value in the building standards process and we feel that we are forced to jump through hoops because the LA Verifier process is the gateway every project commencement.
column32: If we were an unskilled and first time Applicant / Agent then we feel that we would be treated in exactly the same manner. As Chartered Architects we are required to carry full Professional Indemnity for all the work we undertake and have over 30 years of directly relevant design & building experience. The BW process should be a technicality that is administered effectively. It is therefore unfair to treat a skilled professional in the same way as an unskilled D.I.Y applicant where every base has to be covered by correspondence and paperwork. You waste our time as much as you waste your own!
column34: We have dealings with Building Standard from other Local Authority areas and The Moray Council continues to be the most difficult and time consuming LA from which to obtain a BW Consent for a small scale domestic application for a single dwelling .
column35: Each of our BW submissions are directly informed by the BW Consents & process undertaken previously. We have made over 300 submissions small scale domestic application for a single dwellings. It takes longer now for each BW Consent to be processed despite our technical expertise and knowledge of what has gone before. This cannot be an effective use of time, resources or due process. At some point Scottish Government must realise the need for Professional based Self-Certification for the Domestic Building Standards. As Chartered Architects & Certified Passivhaus Designers we must be permitted to work effectively to support the the public sector in delivering more and better quality housing.

column30: The information required is difficult to navigate and isn't compiled in the same order as it needs to be read/ utilised. The construction compliance and notification plan is right at the end of the suite of documents supplied when it needs to be directly after the notification of start of works. The forms also aren't sufficiently tailored to the specific project so it isn't clear what is necessary and what isn't. It would help if the list of supporting documents was listed on the completion certificate document itself. A "Form Q " is referenced as being part of the "Structural Certificate", but there's no explanation as to what this is or whether it's required. There is a list of examples of "any other required certification" which again it would be helpful to know what is required.

column39: Lack of telephone contact
column51:
Need direct telephone build control people.
E mail far two slow. Could be 24 hr between e mails sent and received.
Not every one sits with a lap top in front of them all day. On site mobile internet is not always good. Also trying to type a response or question by e mail on a mobile telephone key pad is not very easy.
Best provide direct telephone content with your staff.  A 60 or 90 second call can get the required information, rather than waiting to evening or following morning to send an e mail. Far tow slow.

column46:
one building controller should deal with the same project from start to finish. 
In the unlikely event that the same person has long term illness or for whatever reason can not continue with the same project, whoever is being sent to deal with the matter MUST take into consideration the history of back and forth, agreements made, concessions made (depending on what the circumstance was) and proceed from there on. In my case, it was a waste of time, plus more money and frustration to go back and forth because one controller had agreed something with us which we did and the final visit we were surprised by a new person who had never been part of the project and asked us to change over 10 things which we had already communicated and approved etc.. It was not fun or effective, I only managed to sort it out by raising the case with the manager and explaining the situation. The manager was very reasonable and sorted it out quickly but it shouldnt really go that far for something considered to be a simple process.
column48: It's important to clarify (taking the previous comment into consideration), the OUTCOME was fair because manager and the previous controller was involved. otherwise the process was NOT a fair treatment at all and caused a lot of unnecessary stress and hassle and more money.
column50: overall, I was not very satisfied. I was satisfied to get it done with. So I'm not sure whether my feeling of part satisfaction came from just getting it done at the end after all the back and forth. my dissatisfied feeling is stronger because of the longer time it took being dissatisfied..
column51:
- the controller assigned on one project should have continued to the end. because they are best placed with the knowledge of the circumstances and agreements made (specifically when external parties were involved to sort out specific matters). 
- lack of knowledge by some of the controllers.. The second controller who came by had not much knowledge about technical aspects but insisted all changes be made based on his logic - even though he colleague plus the architect, and the engineer and technical experts told him otherwise (the change only happened because at the end his boss also told him otherwise).
- it would have been good to have a CERITIFCATE of completion. I didnt get any documents telling me or confirming that the work has been finalised - but i submitted the application for completion. It was only confirmed to me in an email when i asked about it (that no further documents will be sent and that all is good etc..) I would have liked to have an official document or digital confirmation so when i come to sell the property i have everything in order.

column81:
We find the nature and extent of objections being raised on Warrant Reports are increasingly frustrating and without the opportunity to sit down and review face to face in your offices these often result in a time consuming process.  Phone call to officers to discuss reports are largely ignored and seldom returned and we have to wonder if this is a result of allowing home working. 

It would be interesting to know from your records if warrant applications processes have increased over the last 3-4 years
column83:
Unanswered phone calls and no replies to emails with very few exceptions.

Also doesn't help that email attachments can't be sent directly to officers, this is often a good way to communicate a issue before submitting to eDevelopment and having to wait for a reply in the next report.
column87:
By way of example on a current BW application we have left 2 emails and 3 voice messages over 2 weeks with no reply from the officer.

10 days target to reply to an email is far too long
column89: In the end matter do get resolved but the process is more difficult than it should be.
column91: Lack of communications form your department and ability to discuss BW reports.
column92:
Regulations are more complex and do demand more detail, as an office we try to prepare as complete a Warrant package as possible but it seems that the more information that is submitted the longer the objections lists are.   In fairness this is not always down to CEC and we must strive to present things in a clear manner.

Fire Engineers reports are increasingly common on our projects but we do not understand your departments process for considering these specialist matters, currently it the process is very slow.   Who is it in CEC that makes the decisions on the Fire Engineers professional views ?

column37: The application process tends to be very quick; registration of app; assessment of app; communication with assessing officer normally to a high standard, through to the timely release of the BW approval. Very efficient, especially in direct reflection to other Scottish LA Building Standard Departments.
column39: The Building Standards Team tend to be very responsive. Not always available at the desired moment but always tend to come back within a reasonable and acceptable working timescale.
column46: As above, the BS team are approachable; knowledgeable; tend to appear like they want to assist with any queries/ care about your query; are responsive and generally most queries are responded to quickly and efficiently. All of which as a small working practice, is very much appreciated.
column48: We are asked prudent questions on applications and treated with a fair approach to regulations when it comes to those more "grey areas" of definition of terms etc.
column50: The Building Standards Team tend to be very responsive and approachable. The timely nature of application process is much appreciated.
column51: Over all, we would like to comment that the team at WLC Building Standards appear to provide a service which outstrips some of those similar departments at other LAs. The team offer a support and assistance which as a small working practice is appreciated from a local council. The considered approach is appreciated as this tends to allow a smooth BW application process for all involved. We hope this is passed along to the team in good faith.

column16: Both agent and applicant as a Chartered Architectural Technologist
column24: Although we were not bound to a specific timescale, we found that there were a number of obstacles placed before us at many stages of the project.  This included a delay of approximately 9 months in the initial warrant stage to deal with drainage conditions on site.  Whilst we concede that the proposed solution was not standard, the verifier was reluctant to accept the guidance of a certified hydrologist.  The warrant was finally approved through engagement with BSD and LABSS.
column26: As stated in the previous question, the verifier provided poor communication in dealing with the initial warrant stage.
column30: By information I take this to mean the Technical Handbook.  However, where the design approach deviates from the guidance in the handbook verifiers appear unsure how to proceed and reluctant to make decisions.
column32: At many stages of the process we found that unfair demands were being placed upon us, particularly when compared with other development projects which we have experience of.
column34: The development which we undertook exceeds the Building Standards in many respects - environmental, energy efficiency, structural etc.- particularly compared to the mass-produced housing in our area.  As a single developer we appeared to be dealt with more harshly than the big developers.
column35: Whilst we understand the need for a rigorous process which maintains standards we don's feel that we have always been dealt with in fair and equitable manner compared with other projects which we have experience of.

column26: Worse than poor.  We have regularly been waiting for over 12 minths for responses
column30: We have had to escallate matters to MSP and MP levels to get even the  most basic response - and even that didn't work
column35: We pay for a service - Building warrants cost a great deal of money - and we don not receive a anything that could be classified as a service.   As there is no mechanism to sue the council for failure to meet its obligations we are, regretably, stuck with having to put up with a service which is, under any definition, not fit for purpose.

column37:
Generally the Building Standards at West Lothian is too over officious. Warranty applications are made and numerous items returned even when there is significant information submitted by various professionals. It is then difficult to clear these objections as these are delivered in one line answers or could be explained using common sense approach. In addition, items are added to the list after the initial report which makes it impossible for professionals, clients and contractors to accurately price, programme and evaluate a project.
Of all the Local Authorities, West Lothian Council is particularly bad in making the warrant process a sensible and helpful journey. My understanding from developers is that the whole approach stifles investment and development within the area.
Also very unhelpful, West Lothian Council are the only Local Authority I know that will not make a completion inspection to a property if an Amendment to Warrant is pending. Even if the amendment has been requested by the council. The amendments inevitably take weeks/months to process and the building user is left frustrated.
column39: Communication is reasonable. However, it seems mostly ticking a box. The Building Standards department is quick to respond to return drawings during warrant application but without working with professionals to help clear the items and often adding more items. Therefore, it is all good sending back to the agent quickly but overall communication and procedure very poor. Noted it is stated on your return letters "For your information, during the financial year 2021/2022 we granted 99.91% of all applications within 10 days of receiving all the necessary information". I find this misleading as it doesn't mention the unnecessary hoops being asked to get to the point of "receiving all the necessary information". Of course its easy to issue a warrant within 10 days after 6 months

column35: I had the misfortune to have Sara-Louise McClintock assigned to the building warrant for my disabled client who wished to add a very small (less than 4m²) porch extension to her home to improve access and egress for her. Sara-Louise frustrated the process and made inappropriate comments over a phone call of the 6 March 2024 at 13:20 when I called her asking for assistance on one of the queries in her warrant report. The query in question was asking for a fire-test certificate from a cladding manufacturer for untreated wood. Having spoken to several cladding manufacturers and wood associations, they all stated it was a well-known industry fact that untreated wood achieves class D or E for spread of fire - indeed, TRADA state that timber can be used for fire-stopping cavities around windows. When I made this point to Sara-Louise she did not accept it. When I asked her what other agents had provided her in the past, she told me, 'They've given me what I asked for'. When I pushed this further, she asked me, 'why does the client want to use timber cladding - it won't look good'. I was stunned by this question and repeated it to her to clarify - hopefully you record all your calls and pull this one up. Not only would the warrant officer not provide assistance for the job she undertakes, i.e., assisting with the building regulations, but she then found it appropriate to comment on the design of the proposal. Her attitude and behaviour was completely unacceptable and have resulted in a delay of at least 6 weeks to my client, who meanwhile has not been able to move into her property until the warrant has been approved and works taken place. I cannot express enough how utterly dissatisfied and shocked I am at the service I've received from Midlothian Council - the worst experience of dealing with Councils in my 10 years of being a practicing Architect. I will also be making a formal complaint.

column81:
Often we receive letters that action on behalf of the CC is postponed due to work overload which slows our progress and impacts work negatively. 
This includes missing deadlines given by the ECC itself, slow response to direct communication, receiving a decision or an update on the progress, etc. Despite given longer timeframe for response, often that deadline is also further postponed.
column83: Again, with a slow response to the initial application, getting a report and trying to contact the ECC officer to clarify or discuss the points is almost impossible. This becomes a bigger issue when it comes to progressing with work as simple queries take weeks to be clarified.
column87:
While the majority of the staff body is helpful and professional, the difficulty of reaching an officer or getting a response promptly makes customer service less than agreeable. It has been stressed that the workload has expanded and staff capacity is insufficient at this time - this is a clear enough indication of where the problem is. 
Other than that the provided information is clear enough and easy to access.

Application was subjected to a forensic level of scrutiny i have never experienced before. The Officer measured off 1:100 / 1:200 drawings to somehow prove there was dubity to to a 1:20 section I had provided. I repeatedly asked for a phone call to resolve. 
It took two weeks for the Officer to contact me as I had requested. The 5 minute phone call resolved the issue and the Warrant was granted. 
The Officer noted that their preferred method of contact was email due to hearing issues and that Friday were her "admin day". 
At no point was any of that information passed on to me, the Agent.
No one should have an issue with accommodating any given person's individual circumstances, but with no communication / information forthcoming, how are we expected to know and accommodate that? 
Are Officers genuinely only expected to answer queries one day per week - how can that be considered compatible with the industry we all work within?  
Officers should be allowed reasonable time to deal with here workload, However, there should be an understanding that a quick phone call / review can save time and hassle either at that time or further down the line. Construction is a "live" process - next week is not acceptable.
column87: See above.
column89:
See above. Application was scrutinised beyond reasonable expectation and experience. 
Better communication would has resolved the issue much sooner.
column91: I have had application to Edinburgh reviewed by other Local Authorities due to Edinburgh being too busy. Given my experience above, it would seem that Officers are in part responsible for creating the issues that create these backlogs.

column35:
Time period to register new warrants is excessive. East Renfrewshire Council often register same day or next day whereas my experience with Renfrewshire is that is can take a week or more.

Where officers leave and a warrant is still being assessed this repeatedly is never automatically reallocated. Every occasion its happened to me I've been advised that is should have been automatically reallocated but it never has.

Advice can often be inconsistent between surveyors i.e. one surveyor will accept something and another surveyor on another application will say its not acceptable.

column87:
10 days is simply ridiculous. 

If you want institutional funds to bother investing in Edinburgh, you need to sort this out. a fund or a tenant would rather spend £1m doing up an office in England, because of the approved inspectors speeding up the process, than spending the money in Edinburgh because it takes so long for tenant fit out etc to start on site.
column92: Get quicker responses out. Give proper contact details for building control officers, including mobile numbers. Then you will be on par with England's approved inspectors which are much better to deal with.
